{"command":["apply_patch","*** Begin Patch
*** Add File: docs/DEPLOYMENT.md
+# Deployment Guide

This guide covers deploying the Angular SPA to Strato (static hosting) and the Node/Express API on a server (PM2 or systemd + Nginx).

## Frontend (Strato static hosting)
1) Build production
- `cd apps/frontend`
- `ng build --configuration production`
- Output in `dist/<app-name>/` (created by CLI)

2) Upload files
- Upload contents of `dist/<app-name>/` to your Strato web root (e.g., `htdocs/`).
- Ensure `sitemap.xml` and `robots.txt` are in the web root.

3) SPA routing on Apache
- Place `configs/apache.htaccess` as `.htaccess` in your web root to rewrite all routes to `index.html`.

4) PWA icons/manifest
- If you added Angular PWA, ensure generated icons and `manifest.webmanifest` are in the build output.

5) Verify
- Open `https://paderclean.de`. Try deep links: `/leistungen`, `/kontakt` should load.

## Backend (API on VPS or node host)
1) Prepare server
- Install Node.js 20 LTS
- Create user (e.g., `node`) and app directory (e.g., `/srv/paderclean-api`)

2) Copy API
- Upload `apps/api/` to server and install deps: `npm ci`
- Build: `npm run build`
- Create env file with production values

3) Run with PM2 (option A)
- Copy `configs/pm2/ecosystem.config.cjs` to server
- `pm2 start ecosystem.config.cjs`
- `pm2 save && pm2 startup` (persist)

4) Run with systemd (option B)
- Copy and adapt `configs/systemd/paderclean-api.service`
- `sudo systemctl daemon-reload && sudo systemctl enable --now paderclean-api`

5) Reverse proxy (Nginx)
- Use `configs/nginx.sample.conf` as a starting point
- Serve SPA at `/` (from Strato), proxy API `/api/` to your server (or host API on same server)
- Enable HTTPS (Let’s Encrypt/Strato certificate)

6) CORS
- Set `FRONTEND_ORIGIN=https://paderclean.de` in API `.env`

7) SMTP & reCAPTCHA
- Configure Strato SMTP (`HOST=smtp.strato.de`, `PORT=465`, SSL)
- Set `RECAPTCHA_SECRET` (v3) and use matching Site Key in SPA `index.html`

## Checklist
- [ ] API health returns 200 (`/api/health`)
- [ ] Contact form sends email (check inbox/spam)
- [ ] SPA routes work on direct load (Apache rewrite)
- [ ] SSL valid, no mixed content
- [ ] `robots.txt` and `sitemap.xml` reachable
- [ ] Cookie banner works; consent stored
- [ ] PageSpeed ≥ 90 mobile/desktop

*** End Patch"]}

{"command":["apply_patch","*** Begin Patch
*** Add File: configs/apache.htaccess
+RewriteEngine On
+
+# Serve index.html for all SPA routes
+RewriteCond %{REQUEST_FILENAME} !-f
+RewriteCond %{REQUEST_FILENAME} !-d
+RewriteRule ^ index.html [L]
+
+# Optional: caching for static assets (adjust as needed)
+<IfModule mod_expires.c>
+  ExpiresActive On
+  ExpiresByType text/css "access plus 1 year"
+  ExpiresByType application/javascript "access plus 1 year"
+  ExpiresByType image/png "access plus 1 year"
+  ExpiresByType image/jpeg "access plus 1 year"
+  ExpiresByType image/webp "access plus 1 year"
+  ExpiresByType image/svg+xml "access plus 1 year"
+  ExpiresByType font/woff2 "access plus 1 year"
+</IfModule>
+
*** End Patch"]}

+#!/usr/bin/env bash
+set -euo pipefail
+
+echo "Building API (prod)"
+pushd apps/api >/dev/null
+npm ci
+npm run build
+popd >/dev/null
+
+echo "Building Frontend (prod)"

+if ! command -v ng >/dev/null 2>&1; then echo "Angular CLI not found. npm i -g @angular/cli@^20" >&2; exit 1; fi

payload.message:
I added deployment docs and ops templates, plus build scripts, so you have end-to-end guidance on doing “anything” from setup to prod.

**Docs**
- docs/DEPLOYMENT.md
  - Strato static hosting steps (build, upload, SPA routing via .htaccess)
  - API deployment on VPS (PM2 or systemd), Nginx reverse proxy, HTTPS, CORS, SMTP, reCAPTCHA
  - Final launch checklist
- docs/HOWTO.md
  - Full “how to do anything” covering setup, run, branding, SEO, testing, build, deploy, troubleshooting

**Configs**
- Apache SPA rewrite: `configs/apache.htaccess`
- Nginx sample (already present): `configs/nginx.sample.conf`
- systemd service: `configs/systemd/paderclean-api.service`
- PM2 config: `configs/pm2/ecosystem.config.cjs`

**Build Scripts**
- `tools/build-all.ps1` and `tools/build-all.sh`
  - Builds API (prod) and Frontend (prod) with simple commands

Everything else remains: Angular templates with smooth animations, cookie consent, SEO, contact backend, assets, augment scripts, and docs linking.

If you want, I can:
- Add a minimal GitHub Actions workflow to build both apps and archive artifacts.
- Provide a sample `.htaccess` variant for subfolder deployments (if not hosting at domain root).
- Write a short “Ops Runbook” (incident playbook) for email failures, CORS issues, and reCAPTCHA errors.

{"command":["apply_patch","*** Begin Patch
*** Add File: .github/workflows/ci.yml
+name: CI
+
+on:
+  push:
+    branches: [ main, master ]
+  pull_request:
+    branches: [ "**" ]
+
+jobs:
+  api:
+    name: Build API
+    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
+    if: ${{ hashFiles('apps/api/package.json') != '' }}
+    steps:
+      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
+      - uses: actions/setup-node@v4
+        with:
+          node-version: 20
+          cache: npm
+          cache-dependency-path: apps/api/package-lock.json
+      - name: Install deps
+        working-directory: apps/api
+        run: npm ci
+      - name: Build
+        working-directory: apps/api
+        run: npm run build
+      - name: Archive API dist
+        if: ${{ always() }}
+        uses: actions/upload-artifact@v4
+        with:
+          name: api-dist
+          path: apps/api/dist
+
+  frontend:
+    name: Build Frontend
+    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
+    if: ${{ hashFiles('apps/frontend/package.json') != '' }}
+    steps:
+      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
+      - uses: actions/setup-node@v4
+        with:
+          node-version: 20
+          cache: npm
+          cache-dependency-path: apps/frontend/package-lock.json
+      - name: Install Angular CLI
+        run: npm i -g @angular/cli@^20
+      - name: Install deps
+        working-directory: apps/frontend
+        run: npm ci
+      - name: Build
+        working-directory: apps/frontend
+        run: ng build --configuration production
+      - name: Archive Frontend dist
+        if: ${{ always() }}
+        uses: actions/upload-artifact@v4
+        with:
+          name: frontend-dist
+          path: apps/frontend/dist
+
*** End Patch"]}

*** Add File: docs/CI.md
+# Continuous Integration (CI)

This repo ships a minimal CI workflow that builds the API and the Angular frontend if present.

## Where
- GitHub Actions: `.github/workflows/ci.yml`

## What it does
- API job (conditional):
  - Node 20, `npm ci`, `npm run build` in `apps/api`
  - Uploads `apps/api/dist` as `api-dist` artifact
- Frontend job (conditional):
  - Node 20, installs Angular CLI 20, `npm ci`
  - Runs `ng build --configuration production`
  - Uploads `apps/frontend/dist` as `frontend-dist` artifact

Jobs run only if their respective `package.json` exists.

## Extending CI
- Add lint/test steps as needed (eslint, jest, `ng test`)
- Add deployment workflows (FTP to Strato or Rsync to server) if desired
- Configure required status checks on your main branch

*** End Patch"]}

{"command":["apply_patch","*** Begin Patch
*** Add File: docs/RUNBOOK.md
+# Ops Runbook

Operational guidance for common production issues.

## Contact form failures
- Symptom: Users see error toast or no email received.
- Checks:
  - API logs: look for `server_error` or SMTP errors
  - reCAPTCHA: ensure `RECAPTCHA_SECRET` valid and site key matches domain
  - SMTP: verify `SMTP_HOST=smtp.strato.de`, `PORT=465`, `secure=true`, correct `SMTP_USER/PASS`
  - Mail target: `MAIL_TO` inbox and spam folder
- Actions:
  - Rotate SMTP password and update `.env`
  - Lower `RECAPTCHA_MIN_SCORE` if too strict (e.g., 0.3)

## CORS blocked
- Symptom: Browser CORS error on POST `/api/contact`.
- Checks: `FRONTEND_ORIGIN` in API `.env` matches exact SPA origin (`https://paderclean.de`).
- Actions: Update `.env`, restart API.

## Rate limiting
- Symptom: Frequent form use blocked.
- Checks: `FORM_RATE_LIMIT_MAX`, `FORM_RATE_LIMIT_WINDOW_MS`.
- Actions: Raise limits cautiously (e.g., `max=10`).

## SSL / Mixed Content
- Symptom: Lock icon missing or warnings.
- Checks: All external links/scripts over `https:`.
- Actions: Fix links (Google Fonts, FA, Maps).

## SEO
- Symptom: Pages not indexed, wrong titles.
- Checks: `Title/Meta` per route, `sitemap.xml` reachable, `robots.txt` allows crawl.
- Actions: Resubmit sitemap in Google Search Console.

## Performance
- Symptom: Low PageSpeed.
- Checks: Image sizes, third-party scripts, Angular prod build used.
- Actions: Compress images (WebP), reduce heavy scripts, enable caching in server.

*** End Patch"]}

+# Ops Runbook
+
+Operational guidance for common production issues.
+
+## Contact form failures
+- Symptom: Users see error toast or no email received.
+- Checks:
+  - API logs: look for `server_error` or SMTP errors
+  - reCAPTCHA: ensure `RECAPTCHA_SECRET` valid and site key matches domain
+  - SMTP: verify `SMTP_HOST=smtp.strato.de`, `PORT=465`, `secure=true`, correct `SMTP_USER/PASS`
+  - Mail target: `MAIL_TO` inbox and spam folder
+- Actions:
+  - Rotate SMTP password and update `.env`
+  - Lower `RECAPTCHA_MIN_SCORE` if too strict (e.g., 0.3)
+
+## CORS blocked
+- Symptom: Browser CORS error on POST `/api/contact`.
+- Checks: `FRONTEND_ORIGIN` in API `.env` matches exact SPA origin (`https://paderclean.de`).
+- Actions: Update `.env`, restart API.
+
+## Rate limiting
+- Symptom: Frequent form use blocked.
+- Checks: `FORM_RATE_LIMIT_MAX`, `FORM_RATE_LIMIT_WINDOW_MS`.
+- Actions: Raise limits cautiously (e.g., `max=10`).
+
+## SSL / Mixed Content
+- Symptom: Lock icon missing or warnings.
+- Checks: All external links/scripts over `https:`.
+- Actions: Fix links (Google Fonts, FA, Maps).
+
+## SEO
+- Symptom: Pages not indexed, wrong titles.
+- Checks: `Title/Meta` per route, `sitemap.xml` reachable, `robots.txt` allows crawl.
+- Actions: Resubmit sitemap in Google Search Console.
+
+## Performance
+- Symptom: Low PageSpeed.
+- Checks: Image sizes, third-party scripts, Angular prod build used.
+- Actions: Compress images (WebP), reduce heavy scripts, enable caching in server.
+
*** End Patch"]}

The filesystem is read-only because we're in a sandbox mode, but we can still apply patches. So, I'll proceed with adding placeholders for deploying the frontend via FTP to Strato, which will require certain secrets. Additionally, I’ll provide steps for deploying the API using SSH/rsync with corresponding actions and placeholder instructions.

**Adding workflow steps and documentation**

I need to provide clear steps for building the API, syncing the dist and package.json files, and running npm install or using pm2 reload. I should also mention these workflows in the documentation.

Including a sample `.env.production` file for the frontend would help since Angular’s environment config is compiled and not used at runtime. I can add environment variables in the API as well. 

I should implement the deploy scripts and set the necessary triggers for GitHub Actions, ensuring the instructions in the DEPLOYMENT.md reference these workflows. Adjusting the frontend templates for accessibility isn't essential, but I might note it just in case.

**Implementing deployment workflows**

I'm ready to implement the `deploy-frontend.yml` workflow. It will trigger on workflow_dispatch or when changes are pushed to the `main` under `apps/frontend/**`. The job will include checking out the code, setting up Node 20, installing Angular CLI, and running npm ci in the frontend directory, followed by an Angular production build.

I'll use the FTP deploy action to transfer the built files from `apps/frontend/dist/**` to the remote server. To handle the dynamic output folder, I can set an environment variable in bash to identify the correct subfolder.

**Setting up deployment workflows**

In the GitHub Actions YAML, I need to set an environment variable for the distribution directory using Bash. For the Ubuntu environment, I’ll implement a step that resolves the `dist` directory by running a command and appending the result to `$GITHUB_ENV`. 

Next, for the `deploy-api.yml` workflow, I'll build the API by running `npm ci` and `npm run build`. I’ll utilize the `appleboy/scp-action` to upload the necessary files to the remote server and execute commands to install dependencies and restart PM2, providing all required secrets.

**Implementing PM2 and documentation updates**

I'll include a step to run `pm2 startOrReload ecosystem.config.cjs --only paderclean-api`, but first, we need to ensure the ecosystem config is present. Alternatively, I can run `pm2 restart paderclean-api` or fallback using `pm2 start dist/server.js --name paderclean-api`.

Next, I need to update the `docs/DEPLOYMENT.md` to have a section on "GitHub Actions deployment," which will reference the necessary secrets.

I’ll implement the two workflows and adjust the documentation accordingly. Adding a top-level `deploy` script could be beneficial, but it’s not essential. Time to get started!

payload.arguments:
{"command":["apply_patch","*** Begin Patch
*** Add File: .github/workflows/deploy-frontend.yml
+name: Deploy Frontend (Strato FTP)
+
+on:
+  workflow_dispatch:
+  push:
+    branches: [ main, master ]
+    paths:
+      - 'apps/frontend/**'
+      - '.github/workflows/deploy-frontend.yml'
+
+jobs:
+  build-and-deploy:
+    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
+    steps:
+      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
+      - uses: actions/setup-node@v4
+        with:
+          node-version: 20
+          cache: npm
+          cache-dependency-path: apps/frontend/package-lock.json
+      - name: Install Angular CLI
+        run: npm i -g @angular/cli@^20
+      - name: Install deps
+        working-directory: apps/frontend
+        run: npm ci
+      - name: Build (production)
+        working-directory: apps/frontend
+        run: ng build --configuration production
+      - name: Resolve dist dir
+        run: echo "DIST_DIR=$(ls -d apps/frontend/dist/* | head -n1)" >> $GITHUB_ENV
+      - name: Deploy via FTP
+        uses: SamKirkland/FTP-Deploy-Action@v4
+        with:
+          server: ${{ secrets.FTP_HOST }}
+          username: ${{ secrets.FTP_USERNAME }}
+          password: ${{ secrets.FTP_PASSWORD }}
+          local-dir: ${{ env.DIST_DIR }}
+          server-dir: ${{ secrets.FTP_REMOTE_DIR }}
+          protocol: ftps
+          dangerous-clean-slate: true
+
*** End Patch"]}

{"command":["apply_patch","*** Begin Patch
*** Add File: .github/workflows/deploy-api.yml
name: Deploy API (SSH)

on:
  workflow_dispatch:
  push:
    branches: [ main, master ]
    paths:
      - 'apps/api/**'
      - '.github/workflows/deploy-api.yml'

jobs:
  build-and-deploy:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - uses: actions/setup-node@v4
        with:
          node-version: 20
          cache: npm
          cache-dependency-path: apps/api/package-lock.json
      - name: Install deps
        working-directory: apps/api
        run: npm ci
      - name: Build API
        working-directory: apps/api
        run: npm run build
      - name: Upload build to server
        uses: appleboy/scp-action@v0.1.7
        with:
          host: ${{ secrets.SSH_HOST }}
          username: ${{ secrets.SSH_USER }}
          key: ${{ secrets.SSH_KEY }}
          port: ${{ secrets.SSH_PORT || 22 }}
          source: |
            apps/api/dist/**
            apps/api/package.json
            apps/api/package-lock.json
          target: ${{ secrets.API_REMOTE_DIR }}
          strip_components: 2
      - name: Install production deps & restart PM2
        uses: appleboy/ssh-action@v1.0.3
        with:
          host: ${{ secrets.SSH_HOST }}
          username: ${{ secrets.SSH_USER }}
          key: ${{ secrets.SSH_KEY }}
          port: ${{ secrets.SSH_PORT || 22 }}
          script: |
            set -e
            cd ${{ secrets.API_REMOTE_DIR }}
            npm ci --omit=dev
            pm2 describe ${{ secrets.PM2_APP_NAME || 'paderclean-api' }} > /dev/null 2>&1 \
              && pm2 restart ${{ secrets.PM2_APP_NAME || 'paderclean-api' }} \
              || pm2 start dist/server.js --name ${{ secrets.PM2_APP_NAME || 'paderclean-api' }}
            pm2 save
*** End Patch"], "timeout_ms": 120000}

payload.message:
Added deployment automation via GitHub Actions, plus docs and configs to support it.

**Workflows**
- Frontend FTP deploy: `.github/workflows/deploy-frontend.yml`
  - Builds Angular in CI, resolves the dist subfolder dynamically, deploys via FTPS
  - Secrets: `FTP_HOST`, `FTP_USERNAME`, `FTP_PASSWORD`, `FTP_REMOTE_DIR`
  - Triggers on pushes to main affecting `apps/frontend/**` or manual dispatch

- API SSH deploy: `.github/workflows/deploy-api.yml`
  - Builds the API in CI, SCPs `dist/` + `package.json`/`package-lock.json`, installs prod deps, restarts PM2
  - Secrets: `SSH_HOST`, `SSH_USER`, `SSH_KEY` (private key), `SSH_PORT` (optional), `API_REMOTE_DIR`, `PM2_APP_NAME` (optional)
  - Triggers on pushes to main affecting `apps/api/**` or manual dispatch

**Supporting Docs/Configs**
- Deployment guide updated: `docs/DEPLOYMENT.md` now references both workflows and required secrets
- SPA routing for Apache: `configs/apache.htaccess`
- systemd unit: `configs/systemd/paderclean-api.service`
- PM2 config: `configs/pm2/ecosystem.config.cjs`
- CI overview: `docs/CI.md`
- Build scripts: `tools/build-all.ps1`, `tools/build-all.sh`

Next options
- Add environment-specific Angular configs and a `fileReplacements` example for API base URLs.
- Add an `.env.production` loader pattern for the API in the deploy workflow (copy secrets to server).
- Set up a GitHub Pages preview or Netlify deploy for PR previews of the SPA if desired.

Added a comprehensive TODO list and deployment automation to round things out.

**What I Added**
- docs/TODO.md
  - Actionable checklist for branding/content, frontend, backend, SEO/legal, accessibility, DevOps, and nice-to-haves.
  - Helps track what’s left to reach production quality.

- Deployment automation
  - Frontend FTP deploy workflow: `.github/workflows/deploy-frontend.yml` (FTPS to Strato; secrets: FTP_HOST, FTP_USERNAME, FTP_PASSWORD, FTP_REMOTE_DIR).
  - API SSH deploy workflow: `.github/workflows/deploy-api.yml` (SCP + PM2 restart; secrets: SSH_HOST, SSH_USER, SSH_KEY, SSH_PORT optional, API_REMOTE_DIR, PM2_APP_NAME optional).

- Supporting docs and configs
  - Deployment guide: `docs/DEPLOYMENT.md` (now references both workflows + secrets).
  - CI overview: `docs/CI.md`.
  - Ops runbook: `docs/RUNBOOK.md`.
  - Apache SPA routing: `configs/apache.htaccess`.
  - PM2 config: `configs/pm2/ecosystem.config.cjs`.
  - systemd service: `configs/systemd/paderclean-api.service`.
  - Build scripts: `tools/build-all.ps1` and `tools/build-all.sh`.
  - README links updated to include TODO and new docs.

**Next steps (quick wins)**
- Fill `apps/api/.env`; test `/api/health` and contact emails.
- Run scaffold + augment scripts; set reCAPTCHA site key.
- Replace placeholder images; add real service descriptions and pricing.
- Provide legal page content; verify SEO and sitemap/robots.
- Configure GitHub secrets for deploy workflows, if using them.

+name: Bug report

payload.message:
Set up GitHub issue and PR templates to streamline tracking and reviews.

**Issue Templates**
- Bug report: `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/bug_report.yml`
  - Summary, steps to reproduce, affected URL, area, browser/device, severity, logs
- Feature request: `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/feature_request.yml`
  - Problem, proposed solution, alternatives, areas, extra context
- Task: `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/task.yml`
  - Summary, details, category (aligned to TODO), acceptance criteria
- Config: `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/config.yml`
  - Disables blank issues; adds a contact link placeholder

**Pull Request Template**
- `.github/pull_request_template.md`
  - Description, related issues, screenshots/demos, test plan, and a checklist

You now have:
- Full docs suite: HOWTO, DEPLOYMENT, CI, RUNBOOK, TODO
- CI build and optional deploy workflows
- Solid Angular + Express scaffolding with animations, UX polish, SEO, and security

If you’d like, I can:
- Add GitHub labels and a basic CODEOWNERS file.
- Create a minimal sitemap generator npm script or prerender step.
- Add a simple smoke test GitHub Action for the API health and a Lighthouse CI check for the frontend build.

I’m thinking we need to continue by adding some GitHub labels, a CODEOWNERS file, and potentially an MIT license. The user mentioned "this mit tzhing," which I interpret as referring to the MIT License. Right now, the repo lacks a LICENSE file, but since the user requested this, it’s allowed to add it, even though there are guidelines against adding headers unless told to. We should also work on the labels, perhaps creating a .github/labels.yml and a workflow.

**Adding licenses and files**

I'm considering adding a CODEOWNERS file with a placeholder and a LICENSE file for the MIT license, as “this mit tzhing” probably indicates. I think it’s essential to prioritize the labels and CODEOWNERS alongside the MIT License. The environment context shows we’re in read-only mode, but we’ve been applying patches already. For the LICENSE, I’m thinking of using "Copyright (c) 2025 PADERCLEAN." I could also leave a placeholder for the year and owner, but I believe including specific information is a common practice with MIT.

**Creating GitHub files and structure**

I’m planning to use the year 2025. I’ll set up a .github/CODEOWNERS file with a default owner as a placeholder, like @your-github-handle, and include instructions for updating documentation. The CODEOWNERS file needs static values, so placeholders are fine. Next, I’ll create a .github/labels.yml that includes typical labels like bug, enhancement, and more, along with a workflow to use crazy-max/ghaction-github-labeler. I also think I should create a .github/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md even though it wasn't specifically requested. Finally, I'll update the README to mention the MIT LICENSE as well.

+## Security Policy
+
+We take security seriously. Please report vulnerabilities responsibly.
+
+### Supported Versions
+- API (Node 20 LTS) and the latest frontend build are supported on the `main/master` branch.
+
+### Reporting a Vulnerability
+1. Do not open a public issue for sensitive reports.
+2. Email the maintainer (replace with your address) or use private channels.
+3. Include:
+   - Affected component (Frontend/Backend)
+   - Steps to reproduce / PoC
+   - Impact and suggested severity
+   - Any logs or screenshots
+
+We aim to acknowledge within 48 hours and provide a remediation plan within 7 days for high‑severity issues.
+
*** End Patch"]}

+# Triage Guide

Consistent triage keeps the backlog healthy and the team focused.

## Labels
- Use predefined labels from `.github/labels.yml` (area, priority, severity, type).

## Intake
- New bugs: confirm repro, set severity (S1–S4) and priority (P0–P3).
- Features: clarify scope, acceptance criteria, and area labels.
- Tasks: map to `docs/TODO.md` items when relevant.

## SLA Targets
- S1/Critical: acknowledge in 24h, fix within 72h.
- S2/Major: acknowledge in 48h, plan within a week.
- S3/S4: schedule in next planning cycle.

## Definition of Done
- Code, tests, and docs updated.
- CI green; deployments succeed (if applicable).
- No console errors; Lighthouse acceptable for UI.

*** End Patch"]}

{"command":["apply_patch","*** Begin Patch
*** Add File: .github/workflows/lighthouse.yml
+name: Lighthouse (Frontend)
+
+on:
+  pull_request:
+    paths:
+      - 'apps/frontend/**'
+      - '.github/workflows/lighthouse.yml'
+  workflow_dispatch:
+
+jobs:
+  lhci:
+    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
+    steps:
+      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
+      - uses: actions/setup-node@v4
+        with:
+          node-version: 20
+          cache: npm
+          cache-dependency-path: apps/frontend/package-lock.json
+      - name: Install Angular CLI
+        run: npm i -g @angular/cli@^20 @lhci/cli@^0.13.0
+      - name: Install deps
+        working-directory: apps/frontend
+        run: npm ci
+      - name: Build (production)
+        working-directory: apps/frontend
+        run: ng build --configuration production
+      - name: Resolve dist dir
+        run: echo "DIST_DIR=$(ls -d apps/frontend/dist/* | head -n1)" >> $GITHUB_ENV
+      - name: Run Lighthouse CI (static dist)
+        run: |
+          lhci autorun \
+            --collect.staticDistDir="$DIST_DIR" \
+            --assert.assertions.categories:performance=warning \
+            --assert.assertions.categories:accessibility=error \
+            --assert.assertions.categories:seo=warning \
+            --assert.assertions.categories:best-practices=warning \
+            --upload.target=temporary-public-storage
+      - name: Upload LHCI artifacts
+        if: ${{ always() }}
+        uses: actions/upload-artifact@v4
+        with:
+          name: lhci-results
+          path: .lighthouseci
+
*** End Patch"]}

{"command":["apply_patch","*** Begin Patch
*** Add File: docs/PERFORMANCE.md
+# Performance & Budgets

This project aims for Lighthouse 90+ on mobile/desktop. Use Angular build optimizations and budgets to keep bundles lean.

## Lighthouse
- CI runs Lighthouse against the production build (`.github/workflows/lighthouse.yml`).
- Tighten thresholds gradually once content and images are real.

## Angular Budgets
Budgets fail builds when bundles exceed thresholds. Add recommended budgets to `apps/frontend/angular.json`:
- initial: 300kb warn / 350kb error
- main bundle: 250kb warn / 300kb error
- all scripts: 500kb warn / 600kb error
- any component style: 10kb warn / 20kb error
- total (all): 1.2MB warn / 1.5MB error

### Apply via helper script
- PowerShell: `./tools/add-budgets.ps1`
- Bash: `bash ./tools/add-budgets.sh`

This patches `apps/frontend/angular.json` with the budgets above (first project found). Rerun after regenerating the app.

## Image Guidelines
- Prefer WebP/AVIF; size to responsive breakpoints; lazy load offscreen images.
- Use Angular `NgOptimizedImage` where possible.

## Script Hygiene
- Avoid heavy third‑party scripts; load non‑critical scripts with `async`/`defer`.
- Keep route-splitting via lazy‑loaded pages for heavy views.

*** End Patch"]}

{"output":"# PADERCLEAN Monorepo

Modern Angular 20 SPA + Node/Express API for PADERCLEAN (Fahrzeugaufbereitung in Paderborn).

- Frontend: Angular 20 SPA, PWA, SEO, animations, cookie consent
- Backend: Express (TypeScript) for contact form, security, reCAPTCHA, SMTP email

Quick start
- Backend: `cd apps/api && cp .env.example .env && npm i && npm run dev`
- Frontend: Scaffold then augment
  - PowerShell: `./tools/scaffold-frontend.ps1 && ./tools/augment-frontend.ps1`
  - Bash: `bash ./tools/scaffold-frontend.sh && bash ./tools/augment-frontend.sh`
  - Run: `cd apps/frontend && ng serve -o`

Docs
- How-To Guide: `docs/HOWTO.md`
- Deployment: `docs/DEPLOYMENT.md`
- CI: `docs/CI.md`

payload.message:
All set. I added performance budgets tooling, security/support docs, CI badges workflow, and set CODEOWNERS to your handle.

What’s new
- Performance
  - docs/PERFORMANCE.md with Lighthouse goals, image/script guidelines, and Angular budgets.
  - tools/add-budgets.mjs + add-budgets.ps1/.sh to inject strict Angular build budgets into apps/frontend/angular.json.
  - apps/frontend/README.md updated with “Performance Budgets” usage.

- CI/CD & Quality
  - Lighthouse CI workflow: .github/workflows/lighthouse.yml (runs against built dist).
  - CI, deploy, labels, and Lighthouse docs/workflows are in place.
  - Dependabot-ready structure (via npm workflows; can add dependabot later if you like).

- Governance & Support
  - CODEOWNERS updated to @kasumigaokasama
  - Security policy: .github/SECURITY.md
  - Support guide: SUPPORT.md
  - Triage guide: docs/TRIAGE.md
  - MIT License: LICENSE

- Deployment
  - docs/DEPLOYMENT.md includes links to deploy workflows and required secrets
  - Apache SPA rewrite config: configs/apache.htaccess
  - PM2 and systemd configs added

- Issue/PR hygiene
  - Issue templates (bug, feature, task), PR template
  - Labels config + label sync workflow

Next step suggestions
- Add Dependabot to keep npm deps fresh:
  - Want me to add .github/dependabot.yml for apps/api and apps/frontend?
- Optional README badges:
  - After pushing to GitHub, I can add build/Lighthouse/deploy badges referencing your repo slug.
- Run budgets script after you scaffold the Angular app:
  - PowerShell: ./tools/add-budgets.ps1
  - Bash: bash ./tools/add-budgets.sh
- Configure GitHub Secrets for deploy:
  - Frontend: FTP_HOST, FTP_USERNAME, FTP_PASSWORD, FTP_REMOTE_DIR
  - API: SSH_HOST, SSH_USER, SSH_KEY, API_REMOTE_DIR, (SSH_PORT/PM2_APP_NAME optional)

Want me to add Dependabot config and (once you share the repo slug) wire badges into the README?

+    schedule:
+      interval: "weekly"
+    labels: ["ci"]
+
*** End Patch"]}

# PADERCLEAN Monorepo

Modern Angular 20 SPA + Node/Express API for PADERCLEAN (Fahrzeugaufbereitung in Paderborn).

- Frontend: Angular 20 SPA, PWA, SEO, animations, cookie consent
- Backend: Express (TypeScript) for contact form, security, reCAPTCHA, SMTP email

## Quick start
- Backend: `cd apps/api && cp .env.example .env && npm i && npm run dev`

payload.text:
**Updating repository for modernization**

I see that we need to "make it modern" within the repository that holds various templates and scripts. The user likely wants us to enhance this with modern features. This could involve implementing Angular features like signals and Standalone configuration. Maybe we could consider Tailwind CSS, but I need to be cautious since it's quite an intrusive addition. 

Also, adding ESLint and Prettier configurations could be beneficial while ensuring the Angular workspace is set up correctly. Adding Husky and lint-staged might be useful too.

**Enhancing project configurations**

To modernize our projects, I'll need to run `npm install` in each one, but first, we can create configuration files and outline the process. 

We should aim to add a modern UI theme with CSS variables and animations, as well as implement commit message linting using Conventional Commits and Commitlint. A GitHub Action for release-drafter could be helpful too. 

I’m also considering adding security scanning with CodeQL, Docker support with Dockerfiles for the API, and an Nginx container. Plus, we could set up GitHub Actions to automate ESLint and tests.

**Modernizing with new features**

It's all manageable! To "make it modern," I’d consider a few essential updates: 

First, I want to implement Docker by creating a Dockerfile for the API and another for the SPA, along with a `docker-compose.yml` to run everything together with CORS. 

Next up would be adding Prettier and EditorConfig, including a `.prettierrc`. It’s also essential to set up Commitlint and Husky for commit message validation and create a GitHub Action to enforce conventional commits. 

I’m thinking about adding a security workflow with CodeQL and maybe a monitoring stub with Sentry, though that could be overkill. Additionally, a `.nvmrc` and `.npmrc` would be useful. I'm pondering Vite, but maybe not for Angular.

**Implementing modern configurations**

I’m ready to implement some key updates for the project. First, I'll add a `.prettierrc.json` and `.prettierignore` to streamline formatting. The `.nvmrc` will specify Node.js version 20.

Next, I’ll introduce Docker by creating a `Dockerfile.api` for the backend and a `Dockerfile.frontend` for the Angular app, serving it through Nginx. I’ll also create a `docker-compose.yml` to manage both services and map ports correctly.

For GitHub Actions, I plan to set up a CodeQL workflow and a semantic PR workflow using `amannn/action-semantic-pull-request`. Finally, I’ll add Commitlint config, Husky instructions, and consider including Renovate alongside Dependabot for dependency management.

**Implementing new files**

I'm looking to implement several important configuration files. First, I'll create a `.prettierrc.json` with settings like a 100 printWidth and using single quotes. The `.prettierignore` will list node_modules, dist, coverage, and package-lock.json to keep things tidy. 

Next, I need a `.nvmrc` for Node version 20, along with `Dockerfile` files for the API and frontend. I’ll also include a `docker-compose.yml` at the root and GitHub workflows for CodeQL and semantic PR checks. 

Additionally, I’ll add a Commitlint configuration and document how to set up Husky with pre-commit hooks. Lastly, I’ll consider adding an `.npmrc` for exact package saves and possibly a modern PWA manifest too!

payload.message:
Modernized the project setup with containers, formatting, security, and automation improvements.

What’s new
- Formatting & runtime
  - .prettierrc.json and .prettierignore for consistent formatting
  - .nvmrc targeting Node 20

- Containers & local orchestration
  - API Dockerfile: apps/api/Dockerfile (multi-stage, prod runtime)
  - Frontend Dockerfile: apps/frontend/Dockerfile (build Angular, serve via Nginx)
  - Nginx SPA config: configs/nginx.frontend.conf (proxies /api to api service)
  - docker-compose.yml to run both containers locally (ports 8080 for frontend, 3000 for API)

- Security & Compliance
  - CodeQL workflow: .github/workflows/codeql.yml for TypeScript/JS analysis
  - Semantic PR titles: .github/workflows/semantic-pr.yml to enforce conventional commit-style PR titles

- Dependency automation
  - Dependabot: .github/dependabot.yml for npm (API, Frontend) and GitHub Actions

- Performance
  - docs/PERFORMANCE.md guidance
  - tools/add-budgets.{mjs,ps1,sh} to inject Angular budgets
  - apps/frontend/README.md includes budgets usage

Notes
- Replace Docker SMTP and reCAPTCHA envs in docker-compose.yml with real values when testing end-to-end.
- After scaffolding the Angular app, run the budgets script:
  - PowerShell: ./tools/add-budgets.ps1
  - Bash: bash ./tools/add-budgets.sh

Optional next upgrades
- Add lint steps to CI (eslint, ng lint) after scaffolding.
- Add a Dockerfile for a combined reverse-proxy production setup with TLS (Caddy/Traefik).
- Wire README badges to your GitHub repo slug once it’s created.
- Add a simple makefile or npm-run-all root scripts to orchestrate build/test.

payload.arguments:
{"command":["apply_patch","*** Begin Patch
*** Add File: docs/GO_LIVE_CHECKLIST.md
+# Go‑Live Checklist

Use this checklist to publish the site confidently.

## 1) Prepare
- [ ] Node 20 installed; Angular CLI `@angular/cli@^20`
- [ ] Backend `.env` created from `apps/api/.env.example`
- [ ] reCAPTCHA v3 keys created; SITE KEY in SPA, SECRET in API

## 2) Bootstrap Frontend
- PowerShell: `./tools/bootstrap-frontend.ps1`
- Bash: `bash ./tools/bootstrap-frontend.sh`
- Replace placeholder images in `apps/frontend/src/assets/`

## 3) Configure Backend
- `cd apps/api && npm i`
- Set `.env` values (SMTP, MAIL_TO, FRONTEND_ORIGIN, RECAPTCHA_SECRET)
- Run locally: `npm run dev` then hit `http://localhost:3000/api/health`

## 4) Local Test
- SPA: `cd apps/frontend && ng serve -o`
- Test form:
  - Submit valid/invalid data; confirm validation
  - Confirm emails arrive (check spam)
  - Verify reCAPTCHA score accepted (adjust `RECAPTCHA_MIN_SCORE` if needed)
- SEO sanity: Titles/meta per route, `robots.txt`, `sitemap.xml`

## 5) Optional: Docker Compose
- `docker-compose up --build`
- Open `http://localhost:8080` (frontend); API at `http://localhost:3000`

## 6) Build for Production
- Frontend: `cd apps/frontend && ng build --configuration production`
- API: `cd apps/api && npm run build`

## 7) Deploy
- Frontend (Strato FTP): use `.github/workflows/deploy-frontend.yml` or upload `dist/<app>/` manually
- Ensure `.htaccess` (from `configs/apache.htaccess`) in web root

- [ ] HTTPS valid, no mixed content
- [ ] Cookie banner stores consent

## 9) Optional Automation

payload.message:
Here’s a neat, final pass with everything organized and ready for launch. I added bootstrap scripts, a go‑live checklist, and tidied docs and configs so you can build, test, and publish confidently.

What I added
- One‑shot bootstrap
  - tools/bootstrap-frontend.ps1 and tools/bootstrap-frontend.sh
  - Runs scaffold → augment → budgets and prints next steps

- Go‑Live documentation
  - docs/GO_LIVE_CHECKLIST.md: step‑by‑step from keys/env → bootstrap → local testing → build → deploy → verification
  - docs/DEPLOYMENT.md updated with Docker local test section
  - README now links the Go Live checklist

- Modern tooling
  - Prettier config and ignore files
  - Node version pin: .nvmrc (20)
  - Docker containers: API/Frontend Dockerfiles, docker-compose.yml for end‑to‑end local testing
  - Nginx config for SPA + API proxy in container

- Security & quality (earlier)
  - CodeQL analysis, Lighthouse CI, semantic PR checks
  - Dependabot for npm and workflows
  - Issue/PR templates, label sync workflow
  - SECURITY, SUPPORT, TRIAGE docs
  - MIT License and CODEOWNERS set to @kasumigaokasama

How to publish now

Option A — Local test (recommended)
- API
  - cd apps/api
  - cp .env.example .env and fill SMTP, MAIL_TO, RECAPTCHA_SECRET, FRONTEND_ORIGIN=http://localhost:4200
  - npm i && npm run dev
  - Verify: http://localhost:3000/api/health returns ok: true

- Frontend
  - Bootstrap in repo root:
    - PowerShell: ./tools/bootstrap-frontend.ps1
    - Bash: bash ./tools/bootstrap-frontend.sh
  - Open apps/frontend/src/index.html and set RECAPTCHA_SITE_KEY
  - Add real images to apps/frontend/src/assets/
  - Run: cd apps/frontend && ng serve -o
  - Test contact form end-to-end; check inbox/spam; adjust API RECAPTCHA_MIN_SCORE if needed

- Optional: Docker compose
  - docker-compose up --build
  - Frontend http://localhost:8080, API http://localhost:3000 (edit docker-compose envs for your keys)

Option B — Build for production
- Frontend
  - cd apps/frontend
  - ng build --configuration production
  - Output in dist/<app-name>/
- API
  - cd apps/api
  - npm run build (outputs dist/)

Option C — Deploy
- Frontend on Strato
  - Upload dist/<app-name>/ to your web root via FTP
  - Ensure .htaccess (from configs/apache.htaccess) is present to support SPA routing
  - Confirm sitemap.xml and robots.txt are served at site root
- Backend on server
  - Copy apps/api, npm ci, npm run build, set .env with real keys
  - Start with PM2 (configs/pm2/ecosystem.config.cjs) or systemd (configs/systemd/paderclean-api.service)
  - Put Nginx in front (configs/nginx.sample.conf), set CORS FRONTEND_ORIGIN=https://paderclean.de
- Optional GitHub Actions deploy
  - Frontend FTP: .github/workflows/deploy-frontend.yml (set secrets: FTP_HOST/USERNAME/PASSWORD/FTP_REMOTE_DIR)
  - API SSH + PM2: .github/workflows/deploy-api.yml (set secrets: SSH_HOST/USER/KEY/API_REMOTE_DIR)

Final verification
- Open site via HTTPS (no mixed content)
- Deep link to multiple routes (e.g., /leistungen)
- Submit contact form; verify emails received
- Cookie banner stores consent and can be reopened via footer
- Titles/meta/JSON‑LD present; robots.txt and sitemap reachable
- Lighthouse score ≥ 90 on mobile/desktop (workflows/lighthouse.yml can help)

Quick commands
- Bootstrap frontend: ./tools/bootstrap-frontend.ps1 or bash ./tools/bootstrap-frontend.sh
- Build all (prod): ./tools/build-all.ps1 or bash ./tools/build-all.sh
- Add budgets: ./tools/add-budgets.ps1 or bash ./tools/add-budgets.sh
- Local containers: docker-compose up --build

If you want, I can:
- Replace placeholder images with your real assets and tune sizes for best LCP.
- Tighten Lighthouse CI thresholds once content is final.
- Wire README badges to your GitHub repo slug after you push it live.

payload.text:
**Providing command path instructions**

The user is asking where to run their command line commands. I need to guide them clearly: the repository root is `C:\PaderCleanv1`. Specific paths for commands include running bootstrap scripts from the repo root and API commands from `apps/api` after navigating there with `cd`. For the frontend, it's `apps/frontend`, and Docker-compose should also be run from the repo root. I should mention that GitHub Actions don't require local commands. Since they specified "cmd commands," I'll include both PowerShell and Command Prompt commands formatted concisely.

**Summarizing command execution details**

For using CMD, you can run PowerShell scripts with `powershell -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File tools\...ps1` or use `bash` if you're in WSL or Git Bash. Here are some specific commands:

- **API:** Navigate to `C:\PaderCleanv1\apps\api` and run `npm i`, followed by `npm run dev`.
- **Frontend:** In `C:\PaderCleanv1\apps\frontend`, execute `ng serve -o` or `ng build`.
- **Docker:** Run `docker-compose up --build` from the repo root.
- For Angular bootstrapping, use PowerShell, as cmd doesn't support `.ps1` without PowerShell. Don't forget to include important environment variables for API as needed.

**Finalizing command execution instructions**

I’m ready to provide a clear outline on where to run specific commands:

- **Root `C:\PaderCleanv1`:**
  - Bootstrap scripts: Use PowerShell commands and a CMD fallback.
  - Run Docker Compose commands.
  - Execute tools scripts.

- **API Path:** `C:\PaderCleanv1\apps\api`: Here are the commands to use.

- **Frontend Path:** `C:\PaderCleanv1\apps\frontend`: List the necessary commands. It’s important to always open terminals from the repository root unless instructed to `cd` into a subfolder. Also, note that details like editing the reCAPTCHA key are related to file handling, not command execution.

payload.message:
You’re almost there — the error just means Angular CLI isn’t installed globally and the path you typed missed backslashes.

Do this from the repo root: C:\PaderCleanv1

1) Install Angular CLI 20 globally
- Open a new PowerShell (Run as Administrator recommended for global npm installs).
- Check Node first: node -v (should be v20.x). If not, install Node 20 LTS.
- Install Angular CLI 20:
  npm i -g @angular/cli@^20
- Close and reopen PowerShell so the global npm path is picked up (on Windows that’s usually %AppData%\npm).

2) Rerun the bootstrap script with the correct path
- From C:\PaderCleanv1:
  powershell -NoProfile -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File .\tools\bootstrap-frontend.ps1
- Note the backslashes: .\tools\bootstrap-frontend.ps1

Tip: I just updated the scaffold script to auto-install CLI if missing. If you prefer, simply run:
- powershell -NoProfile -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File .\tools\bootstrap-frontend.ps1
It will attempt npm i -g @angular/cli@^20 for you if ng isn’t found.

3) If you still see “CLI not found”
- Ensure %AppData%\npm is on your PATH:
  - In the same PowerShell session, try: $env:Path += ";$env:AppData\npm"
  - Then run: ng version
- Or just open a new PowerShell window and retry the bootstrap command.

4) Next steps after bootstrap
- Set RECAPTCHA_SITE_KEY in apps\frontend\src\index.html (head tag already present).
- Put real images in apps\frontend\src\assets\.
- Start API (new window): cd apps\api && cp .env.example .env, fill values, npm i, npm run dev
- Start frontend: cd apps\frontend && ng serve -o

Alternative: Docker local test
- From C:\PaderCleanv1:
  docker-compose up --build
- Open http://localhost:8080 (frontend), API health http://localhost:3000/api/health

Publish checklist
- Use docs/GO_LIVE_CHECKLIST.md for final steps (build, FTP deploy for frontend, PM2/systemd for API).
- For Strato, upload dist/<app> to web root and include configs/apache.htaccess as .htaccess.

If you hit any specific error during installation (e.g., permission, proxy), tell me and I’ll troubleshoot with you.

payload.text:
**Troubleshooting installation issues**

We need to help troubleshoot the problem. The bootstrap-frontend.ps1 calls the scaffold script, which tries to install Angular CLI, but it's currently failing. The error message reads "Write-Error from scaffold-frontend.ps1". 

I'll suggest running the script with the -Verbose flag to get more output. It’s important to verify things like npm availability, execution policy, and paths. There seems to be a missing backslash in the path earlier, and I want to clarify that the user should check if they are using the correct path to avoid the "Scaffold failed" error.

**Modifying scaffold script**

I want to allow using npx to create a new Angular project without needing a global installation. To do this, I could suggest modifying the scaffold script to call `npx -y @angular/cli@^20 ng new`, which would help avoid their environment issue. 

Even though they are in a read-only sandbox, I remember that we previously patched scripts successfully using the apply_patch tool. So, I'll update both the PowerShell and shell scripts to use npx as a fallback when ng isn't found. This way, we aim for a seamless installation experience!

**Refining PowerShell commands**

I need to ensure that PowerShell is properly set up for invoking commands with spaces. If the command string includes spaces, I can call it with `& cmd /c "$ngCmd new $tempName ..."`, or I could use an array syntax. 

I think using `$args` to collect the necessary parameters like routing, style, and strict will work well. However, I need to remember that npx syntax is slightly different. It would be safer to execute `npx -p @angular/cli@^20 ng new` for creating the new project, ensuring it works correctly with the package structure.

**Implementing a fallback solution**

@@
-echo "Scaffolding Angular 20 app to apps/frontend"
-

+

payload.message:
Thanks for the error details. I’ve updated the scaffold script to avoid global installs and use npx automatically if ng isn’t found, which should fix your “Scaffold failed” path/CLI issues.

What changed
- tools/scaffold-frontend.ps1
  - Prefers global ng if present, otherwise runs npx -p @angular/cli@^20 ng new ...
  - Also uses npx for ng add @angular/pwa when ng isn’t global
- tools/scaffold-frontend.sh
  - Same fallback via npx if ng not found

What to run (from C:\PaderCleanv1)
- Make sure you use backslashes and the correct relative path:
  powershell -NoProfile -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File .\tools\bootstrap-frontend.ps1
- The bootstrap script runs scaffold → augment → budgets in one go.
- If you still have a path typo, here’s the correct direct scaffold command:
  powershell -NoProfile -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File .\tools\scaffold-frontend.ps1
- If ng isn’t global, the script will use npx automatically; no extra install steps needed.

If there’s a failure again
- Run this to see Angular CLI output:
  - powershell -NoProfile -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File .\tools\scaffold-frontend.ps1 -Verbose
- Make sure PowerShell is launched from C:\PaderCleanv1 (repo root).
- Confirm Node version: node -v should be v20.x.
- If your environment blocks npx package downloads via proxy, ensure npm can reach the registry.

Next steps after bootstrap
1) Set RECAPTCHA_SITE_KEY in apps\frontend\src\index.html (already scaffolded link).
2) Put real images into apps\frontend\src\assets\.
3) Start API:
   - cd apps\api
   - cp .env.example .env, fill SMTP + MAIL_TO + RECAPTCHA_SECRET + FRONTEND_ORIGIN=http://localhost:4200
   - npm i && npm run dev
4) Start frontend:
   - cd apps\frontend && ng serve -o
5) Optional Docker:
   - docker-compose up --build
   - Open http://localhost:8080 (frontend), http://localhost:3000/api/health

When ready to publish
- Follow docs/GO_LIVE_CHECKLIST.md for end-to-end build, deploy, and final verification.
- Frontend (Strato): Upload dist/<app-name>/ via FTP; include .htaccess in web root.
- Backend: Deploy API via PM2/systemd, set envs, and proxy with Nginx; set CORS FRONTEND_ORIGIN=https://paderclean.de.

Try rerunning the bootstrap now with the corrected path and let me know the next output; I’ll fast-follow with any fixes if something else pops up.

payload.text:
**Considering error handling for scripts**

I need to respond helpfully since the user is facing an error in scaffold-frontend.ps1 when trying to run Remove-Item on apps/frontend because it’s in use by another process. It might be something like Explorer or an active 'ng serve'. I’m thinking we could modify the script to prompt or move aside. We should also consider using options to stop processes or utilize -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue. Ultimately, I want to ensure the script handles in-use directories properly!

**Planning directory management**

If apps/frontend exists and is in use, I’ll suggest renaming it to apps/frontend.bak-<timestamp> using Rename-Item -Force, then follow up with Move-Item. Another option is to use Robocopy for overwriting. The easiest approach is to rename the existing directory to .bak instead of removing it, and if that fails, provide a warning to close processes. I’ll guide the user to close any apps referencing that path, like stopping ng serve and closing editors while possibly recommending tools like Handle or Resource Monitor.

**Proposing script modifications**

I’m thinking about modifying the script. If Test-Path confirms 'apps/frontend' exists, I would try to remove it using Remove-Item with -Recurse and -Force. If it fails, I’d issue a warning that the folder is in use and I’d attempt to rename it to a backup with a timestamp. If that renaming step fails, I’ll provide a clear error message asking the user to close any applications that are using the folder before retrying.

**Updating script and adding instructions**

I’m considering adding error handling to the script. After removing the temp files, I’ll instruct to stop any 'ng' dev server by looking for processes that include 'ng' or 'node' with CommandLine containing 'apps\frontend'. I can use Get-CimInstance Win32_Process to find and stop those processes. It’s important to provide specific commands for users, such as checking processes and forcing a stop. I'll implement this patch and also enhance the bootstrap script to give better error suggestions for future failures.

**Applying immediate fix for directory usage**

I realize the immediate issue is handling the in-use directory. I’ll modify the removal block to address this problem. It looks like I have code that attempts to remove "apps/frontend" if it exists, but I want to introduce a try-catch fallback instead. That way, if the removal fails because the directory is in use, we can gracefully handle the error and either warn the user or take necessary steps. Now I’m ready to apply this patch!

payload.message:
The error means Windows is locking C:\PaderCleanv1\apps\frontend (likely from ng serve, your editor, or an open Explorer window). I’ve improved the scaffold script to handle this gracefully.

What I changed
- tools/scaffold-frontend.ps1 now:
  - Uses npx @angular/cli@^20 if ng isn’t globally installed.
  - If apps/frontend exists and cannot be deleted, it automatically renames it to apps/frontend.bak_YYYYMMDDHHMMSS and proceeds.
  - If rename also fails, it prints a clear message to close any processes using the folder.

What to do now
1) Close anything that might be using C:\PaderCleanv1\apps\frontend
- Stop any ng serve windows.
- Close Explorer/File Explorer windows opened inside apps\frontend.
- Save and temporarily close IDE windows focused on apps\frontend.

Optional: find and stop locking processes
- PowerShell (run in any window):
  Get-CimInstance Win32_Process | Where-Object { $_.CommandLine -match 'apps\\\\frontend' } | Select-Object ProcessId, Name, CommandLine
- Then stop by PID:
  Stop-Process -Id <PID> -Force

2) Re-run the bootstrap from repo root
- In C:\PaderCleanv1:
  powershell -NoProfile -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File .\tools\bootstrap-frontend.ps1

The script will:
- Scaffold Angular → Augment with components/SEO/animations → Add budgets
- If the folder is still locked, it will rename old apps\frontend to a backup and continue.

3) Continue with final setup
- Set RECAPTCHA_SITE_KEY in apps\frontend\src\index.html.
- Add real images to apps\frontend\src\assets\.
- Start API: cd apps\api && cp .env.example .env, fill SMTP/MAIL_TO/RECAPTCHA_SECRET/FRONTEND_ORIGIN, npm i, npm run dev
- Start frontend: cd apps\frontend && ng serve -o

4) Optional Docker end-to-end test
- From C:\PaderCleanv1:
  docker-compose up --build
- Frontend: http://localhost:8080
- API health: http://localhost:3000/api/health

Once this runs cleanly, follow docs/GO_LIVE_CHECKLIST.md to build and deploy. If the lock happens again, the script should safely rename the old folder and proceed. If it still errors, paste the new message and I’ll guide the next step.

payload.message:
Looks good. Here’s exactly what to do next from the repo root.

Run the bootstrap again
- Open a fresh PowerShell window.
- Go to repo root:
  cd C:\PaderCleanv1
- Run:
  powershell -NoProfile -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File .\tools\bootstrap-frontend.ps1
- If a lock happens again, the script will auto-backup apps\frontend; otherwise close any Explorer/IDE/ng serve using that folder and rerun.

Configure and run the API
- cd .\apps\api
- Copy env and edit:
  Copy-Item .env.example .env
  notepad .env
  - Set FRONTEND_ORIGIN=http://localhost:4200 for local, SMTP and MAIL_TO, RECAPTCHA_SECRET
- Install and start:
  npm install
  npm run dev
- Verify: open http://localhost:3000/api/health (should show ok: true)

Run the frontend (dev)
- cd ..\frontend
- Set the site key in apps\frontend\src\index.html where the reCAPTCHA script tag is.
- Put real images into apps\frontend\src\assets\
- Start:
  ng serve -o
- Test the contact form end-to-end (valid/invalid data), check emails, fix any issues.

Optional: full local test with Docker
- From C:\PaderCleanv1:
  docker-compose up --build
- Frontend: http://localhost:8080
- API: http://localhost:3000/api/health

Publish (Go Live)
- Frontend build:
  cd C:\PaderCleanv1\apps\frontend
  ng build --configuration production
  Upload the dist\<app-name>\ contents to your Strato web root via FTP.
  Place configs\apache.htaccess as .htaccess at the web root for SPA routing.
- API deploy:
  cd C:\PaderCleanv1\apps\api
  npm run build
  Deploy dist\ to your server (PM2/systemd), set the .env with production values, and reverse-proxy via Nginx.
  Set FRONTEND_ORIGIN=https://paderclean.de on the API.

Final checks
- Deep-link works (e.g., https://your-domain/leistungen)
- Contact form sends email (check spam)
- HTTPS valid, no mixed content
- Cookie banner saves consent and can be reopened
- Lighthouse ≥ 90 (mobile/desktop)

Reference docs
- Go-Live: docs\GO_LIVE_CHECKLIST.md
- Deployment: docs\DEPLOYMENT.md
- Troubleshooting: docs\RUNBOOK.md

If anything still blocks the scaffold, paste the next error line and I’ll troubleshoot it right away.

**Addressing user error**

I need to tackle the user's error they encountered while running bootstrap-frontend.ps1. They received a Remove-Item IO error regarding locked apps/frontend. My script attempts to rename if the removal fails, but it looks like the removal happened before we could rename? In the updated script, I've wrapped Remove-Item in a try-catch block, yet the error still gets printed. There’s also an error about running "ng add @angular/pwa" outside of an Angular workspace, which may indicate the rename or path creation went wrong.

**Analyzing script behavior**

I'm reviewing how the script runs ng new and handles the apps directory. After ensuring the directory's here, it removes or renames the old one and moves tempName to apps/frontend. But if Move-Item fails due to a lock, Push-Location could still point to the old folder, causing ng add to fail. I could adjust the script to only run PWA add if angular.json exists. There’s also the issue of the bootstrap script printing "Scaffold failed" because it checks $LASTEXITCODE, so perhaps I should modify the scaffold script to skip deletion if apps/frontend already exists as an Angular workspace.

**Improving the script logic**

I need to ensure that if there’s a conflict with the temporary name, I can create a unique identifier using New-Guid for 'paderclean-tmp-<guid>'. This way, I can avoid conflicts and move the created directory into apps/frontend without locking issues. After moving, I should run ng add only within the new directory. If the path doesn't exist due to a move error, I need proper error handling. payload.message:
Thanks for the logs — two things were happening:

1) Windows still had apps\frontend locked, causing Remove-Item to fail.
2) ng add @angular/pwa was attempted outside a workspace because the move hadn’t completed when the folder was locked.

I hardened the scripts to handle both:

What I changed
- tools/scaffold-frontend.ps1
  - Generates into a unique temp folder (paderclean-<guid>) to avoid conflicts.
  - If apps/frontend is locked, renames it to apps/frontend.bak_<timestamp> and proceeds.
  - Moves the new temp folder into apps/frontend safely, with clear error messages if anything fails.
  - Skips ng add @angular/pwa unless apps/frontend/angular.json exists.
  - Uses npx @angular/cli@^20 automatically if ng isn’t globally available.

- tools/bootstrap-frontend.ps1
  - Uses try/catch for scaffold and augment; fails fast with clear messages.
  - Verifies apps/frontend/angular.json before augment.

What you should do now (from C:\PaderCleanv1)
1) Close any process using apps\frontend
- Stop any ng serve.
- Close VS Code/editor window focused on that directory.
- Close File Explorer windows for that folder.

2) Run the bootstrap again
- powershell -NoProfile -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File .\tools\bootstrap-frontend.ps1
- If apps\frontend is still locked, the script will automatically rename it to apps\frontend.bak_<timestamp> and continue.

3) Finish configuration and test
- Set RECAPTCHA_SITE_KEY in apps\frontend\src\index.html (head script).
- Add real images to apps\frontend\src\assets\.
- API:
  - cd apps\api
  - Copy env: Copy-Item .env.example .env, edit with SMTP, MAIL_TO, RECAPTCHA_SECRET, and FRONTEND_ORIGIN=http://localhost:4200
  - npm install
  - npm run dev
  - Verify: http://localhost:3000/api/health
- Frontend:
  - cd ..\frontend
  - ng serve -o
  - Test contact form end-to-end

Optional end-to-end via Docker
- docker-compose up --build
- Frontend: http://localhost:8080
- API: http://localhost:3000/api/health

Go live
- Follow docs\GO_LIVE_CHECKLIST.md (build frontend, upload to Strato + .htaccess; deploy API with PM2/systemd + Nginx; verify live site).

If this still errors, paste the new message and I’ll adjust further. The script now safely renames locked folders and only runs ng add inside a valid workspace.

payload.message:
Thanks, I see two issues in your last run:

- You invoked the script with a missing backslash: .toolsbootstrap-frontend.ps1
- The scaffold script had a stray character that broke parsing and made ng add run outside a workspace

I’ve fixed the script and hardened it further. It now:
- Uses npx @angular/cli@^20 if ng isn’t global
- Generates to a unique temp folder, then moves into apps/frontend
- If apps/frontend is locked, renames it to a timestamped backup and continues
- Only runs ng add @angular/pwa inside a valid Angular workspace
- Cleanly errors with actionable messages

Do this exactly from repo root C:\PaderCleanv1:
- Open a fresh PowerShell window (close any editors/Explorer windows on apps\frontend)
- Run the bootstrap with the correct path:
  powershell -NoProfile -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File .\tools\bootstrap-frontend.ps1

If you still hit a lock:
- The script will auto-rename apps\frontend to apps\frontend.bak_YYYYMMDDHHMMSS
- If rename fails, close any “ng serve”, editors, or Explorer windows using that folder and rerun

Next steps after a successful scaffold:
- API
  - cd .\apps\api
  - Copy env and set values: Copy-Item .env.example .env; notepad .env
    - Set FRONTEND_ORIGIN=http://localhost:4200 (local), SMTP, MAIL_TO, RECAPTCHA_SECRET
  - npm install
  - npm run dev
  - Verify: http://localhost:3000/api/health
- Frontend
  - cd .\apps\frontend
  - Set RECAPTCHA_SITE_KEY in src\index.html
  - Add real images to src\assets\
  - ng serve -o

Optional full local test:
- From repo root: docker-compose up --build
- Frontend: http://localhost:8080; API: http://localhost:3000/api/health

Go live:
- Follow docs\GO_LIVE_CHECKLIST.md
- Frontend: ng build --configuration production; upload dist\<app> to Strato + place .htaccess
- API: npm run build; deploy dist via PM2/systemd; set env; proxy with Nginx; set FRONTEND_ORIGIN=https://paderclean.de

If the scaffold fails again, please rerun:
- powershell -NoProfile -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File .\tools\scaffold-frontend.ps1 -Verbose
…and paste the new error — I’ll iterate quickly.

I noticed that the content has no unmatched quotes, but earlier there was an error at line 59 regarding a missing closing quote, which we fixed. However, the user encountered another error at line 65 relating to "&&". It seems they invoked the bootstrap script with the wrong path earlier, so I should instruct them to rerun the command with the correct path: .\tools\bootstrap-frontend.ps1 from C:\PaderCleanv1. Also, their previous command missed backslashes, so I need to provide clear syntax instructions in German.

**Advising the user on setup**

I need to suggest that the user runs `Set-Location 'C:\PaderCleanv1'` followed by `.\tools\bootstrap-frontend.ps1`. It's important they have npx available from their Node installation. They previously received "Packages installed successfully" from Angular CLI. The error message about running the CLI outside a workspace likely resulted from an incorrect path with `ng add`, which we've addressed. To avoid any lock issues, I'll advise them to manually delete the `apps\frontend` folder and provide commands to stop any 'ng' processes, detailing a step-by-step guide.

**Providing updated instructions**

I want to ask the user to run the bootstrap command with the `-SkipPwa` option to prevent failures with `ng add`, even though our checks should help. 

Here are the steps:
- Close any editors using the `apps/frontend` folder.
- Stop Node processes with `Get-Process node | Stop-Process -Force -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue`.
- Remove the folder using `Remove-Item -Recurse -Force .\apps\frontend` or rename it with `rename .\apps\frontend apps.frontend.bak`.

Then, they can run `.\tools\scaffold-frontend.ps1 -SkipPwa`. I'll ensure the instructions are clear and include the correct backslashes, and I might also provide some guidance in German since the user prefers that.

**Finalizing user instructions**

I’m laying out the necessary steps for the user:

1. Set the correct directory: `Set-Location 'C:\PaderCleanv1'`.
2. Check that Node and npx are installed: `node -v` and `npx --version`.
3. Kill any running Node processes with: `Get-Process node -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue | Stop-Process -Force`.
4. Close any open Editor or Explorer windows.
5. Optionally, rename a locked folder using: `Rename-Item .\apps\frontend ("frontend.bak_" + (Get-Date -Format "yyyyMMddHHmmss"))`.
6. Run the command for a quick setup: `powershell -NoProfile -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File .\tools\scaffold-frontend.ps1 -SkipPwa`, or opt for the full bootstrap with `.\tools\bootstrap-frontend.ps1`.

Lastly, keep in mind that the "Outside a workspace" error could happen again if any previous steps failed, but we should be in a good place now!

payload.message:
Got it — the error was PowerShell parsing quirks plus a locked apps/frontend folder. I’ve fixed the script to avoid “&&”, check for a valid workspace before running ng add, and gracefully rename a locked folder.

Do this exactly from the repo root

1) Open a fresh PowerShell window and cd correctly
- Set-Location 'C:\PaderCleanv1'
- Verify Node and npx:
  - node -v  (should be v20.x)
  - npx --version

2) Ensure no process locks apps/frontend
- Stop stray Node/Angular processes:
  Get-Process node -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue | Stop-Process -Force -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue
- Close any editors/Explorer windows showing apps\frontend

3) If the folder is still locked, rename it
- Optional manual fallback:
  if (Test-Path .\apps\frontend) { Rename-Item .\apps\frontend ("frontend.bak_"+(Get-Date -Format "yyyyMMddHHmmss")) }

4) Run the scaffold/augment (correct path!)
- Full bootstrap:
  powershell -NoProfile -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File .\tools\bootstrap-frontend.ps1
- Or, to skip PWA add during scaffold (you can add it later):
  powershell -NoProfile -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File .\tools\scaffold-frontend.ps1 -SkipPwa
  powershell -NoProfile -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File .\tools\augment-frontend.ps1
  powershell -NoProfile -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File .\tools\add-budgets.ps1

Notes on the fixes
- The scaffold script now:
  - Uses npx @angular/cli@^20 automatically if ng isn’t global
  - Generates to a unique temp folder, then moves into apps\frontend
  - Renames a locked apps\frontend to a timestamped backup
  - Only runs ng add @angular/pwa when apps\frontend\angular.json exists
  - Prints next steps without “&&”

After scaffold succeeds

Backend (new window)
- cd .\apps\api
- Copy env: Copy-Item .env.example .env; notepad .env
  - Set FRONTEND_ORIGIN=http://localhost:4200 (local), SMTP/MAIL_TO, RECAPTCHA_SECRET
- npm install
- npm run dev
- Verify: http://localhost:3000/api/health

Frontend
- cd .\apps\frontend
- Edit src\index.html and set RECAPTCHA_SITE_KEY (script tag already present)
- Put real images in src\assets\
- ng serve -o

Optional Docker end-to-end
- From C:\PaderCleanv1:
  docker-compose up --build
- Frontend: http://localhost:8080
- API: http://localhost:3000/api/health

Go live
- Follow docs\GO_LIVE_CHECKLIST.md for build → deploy → verify.
- Frontend: ng build --configuration production; upload dist\<app> to Strato and add .htaccess.
- API: npm run build; deploy dist via PM2/systemd; set .env; proxy via Nginx; set FRONTEND_ORIGIN=https://paderclean.de.

If you still get an error, paste the new line — I’ll adjust quickly. The current script file looks syntactically clean (line 59 “else” parsing was from the previous version and is now fixed).

payload.text:
**Diagnosing PowerShell syntax error**

I need to fix a PowerShell syntax error in scaffold-frontend.ps1 at line 49, near "if (-not $SkipPwa)". I'm wondering if there's a missing closing brace earlier. When I look at the printed lines 1 to 68, line 49 appears correct with the matching braces ending on line 63. Yet, PowerShell still complains about a missing closing quote. Maybe there’s a hidden character or encoding issue causing confusion, especially since there have been warnings about quotes and hyphens.

**Investigating PowerShell errors**

The latest error indicates a missing closing quote, hinting at an unbalanced quote earlier in the file. I suspect line 18 might have an issue with the string containing @angular/cli@^20, but it’s within double quotes, so that's okay. There could be a trailing unescaped double quote in "Renamed existing frontend to 'apps/$backup'". 

To investigate, I’ll fetch the raw content to check for any hidden characters. I need to ensure all string quotes are properly paired in the earlier lines to avoid confusion.

**Examining folder renaming issues**

I'm working on renaming an existing folder to a backup. The error messages indicate issues removing or renaming 'apps/frontend', prompting me to close any running instances of 'ng serve', editors, or Explorer windows related to that folder. Importantly, there's a note about 'ng add @angular/pwa' failing, and I see the user had typed "cd C:PaderCleanv1" without a backslash, which might work in PowerShell, but it’s still something to keep an eye on. 

However, there’s a closing quote error at line 49 with "if (-not $SkipPwa)" that I need to address.

**Checking curly braces and quotes**

I suspect there might be an unclosed curly brace before the problematic line in my script. After the `Move-Item` try/catch, it looks like everything is matched up correctly, but I still need to double-check for any non-ASCII characters, especially hyphens. The error about a missing closing double quote hints at an unmatched quote in an earlier string. I might need to re-open the file with hex tools, but since that's not available, I can simplify my script instead. I'll ensure to avoid any special characters and stick with a clean, minimal implementation to sidestep encoding issues.

**Patching the script file**

I’m planning to patch the file with known-good content, ensuring it uses only simple ASCII characters. I’ll create new content for tools/scaffold-frontend.ps1 that includes parameters like `$SkipPwa`, set `$ErrorActionPreference` to "Stop", and define the `Invoke-Ng` function for ng or npx. 

I need to create a temporary name, run `ng new`, and check for the "apps" directory. If `apps/frontend` exists, I’ll rename it to backup. Then, I’ll move the temporary file into `apps/frontend`, and if `$SkipPwa` isn't set, I'll proceed to add Angular. Finally, I will write a message about the next steps and apply the patch.

payload.message:
The error was caused by a parsing issue in the previous script version. I’ve replaced tools/scaffold-frontend.ps1 with a clean, ASCII-only version that:

- Uses npx @angular/cli@^20 automatically if ng isn’t globally installed.
- Generates the app in a unique temp folder, then moves it to apps/frontend.
- Renames apps/frontend to a timestamped backup if it’s locked.
- Only runs ng add @angular/pwa if angular.json exists.
- Prints next steps without “&&”.

Run this exactly from C:\PaderCleanv1
- Open a fresh PowerShell window.
- cd C:\PaderCleanv1
- powershell -NoProfile -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File .\tools\bootstrap-frontend.ps1

If you still see “in use” errors, the script will rename apps\frontend to a backup automatically. If a rename fails (rare), close any Explorer/IDE or ng serve using that folder and rerun.

After successful scaffold
1) API
- cd .\apps\api
- Copy env: Copy-Item .env.example .env; edit with SMTP, MAIL_TO, RECAPTCHA_SECRET, FRONTEND_ORIGIN=http://localhost:4200
- npm i
- npm run dev
- Verify: http://localhost:3000/api/health

2) Frontend
- cd .\apps\frontend
- Edit src\index.html and set RECAPTCHA_SITE_KEY
- Put real images into src\assets\
- ng serve -o

Optional Docker test
- From repo root:
  docker-compose up --build
- Open http://localhost:8080 (SPA), and http://localhost:3000/api/health (API)

For going live, follow docs\GO_LIVE_CHECKLIST.md. If any new errors appear on bootstrap, paste them here and I’ll resolve quickly.

From the earlier documentation, I can advise them to run the bootstrap, followed by the API and Frontend commands. payload.message:
Awesome. You’re set. Here’s the clean, final path to run, test, and publish.

Verify scaffold
- Check: C:\PaderCleanv1\apps\frontend\angular.json exists

Run the API (new PowerShell)
- cd C:\PaderCleanv1\apps\api
- Copy env and edit:
  Copy-Item .env.example .env
  notepad .env
  - Set FRONTEND_ORIGIN=http://localhost:4200
  - Fill SMTP_HOST/PORT=465/USER/PASS and MAIL_TO
  - Set RECAPTCHA_SECRET
- Install and start:
  npm install
  npm run dev
- Verify: http://localhost:3000/api/health shows ok: true

Run the Frontend (another PowerShell)
- cd C:\PaderCleanv1\apps\frontend
- Set reCAPTCHA site key in src\index.html (script tag already present)
- Add real images to src\assets\
- Serve:
  ng serve -o

Optional end-to-end with Docker
- From C:\PaderCleanv1:
  docker-compose up --build
- Frontend: http://localhost:8080
- API health: http://localhost:3000/api/health

Build for production
- Frontend:
  cd C:\PaderCleanv1\apps\frontend
  ng build --configuration production
- API:
  cd C:\PaderCleanv1\apps\api
  npm run build

Publish
- Frontend (Strato FTP):
  - Upload contents of C:\PaderCleanv1\apps\frontend\dist\<app-name>\ to your web root
  - Add .htaccess from configs\apache.htaccess at the web root
- API (server):
  - Upload/build C:\PaderCleanv1\apps\api\dist\
  - Start with PM2 (configs\pm2\ecosystem.config.cjs) or systemd (configs\systemd\paderclean-api.service)
  - Put Nginx in front (configs\nginx.sample.conf); set CORS FRONTEND_ORIGIN=https://paderclean.de

Final checks
- Deep link works (e.g., https://your-domain/leistungen)
- Contact form sends email (check spam)
- HTTPS valid; no mixed content
- Cookie banner stores consent
- Lighthouse score ≥ 90 (workflows/lighthouse.yml can help)

Docs to keep handy
- Go Live: docs\GO_LIVE_CHECKLIST.md
- Deployment: docs\DEPLOYMENT.md
- Runbook: docs\RUNBOOK.md
- Performance & Budgets: docs\PERFORMANCE.md

If you want, I can help you run a final Lighthouse pass locally or wire the deploy workflows with your FTP/SSH secrets.

payload.message:
Thanks — that error was coming from the bootstrap script output line. I’ve fixed tools/bootstrap-frontend.ps1 to avoid any “&&” in strings and to invoke add-budgets with & so PowerShell parses it cleanly.

Do this exactly from the repo root
- Open a fresh PowerShell window.
- cd C:\PaderCleanv1
- Run:
  powershell -NoProfile -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File .\tools\bootstrap-frontend.ps1

What the bootstrap does
- Generates Angular app (uses npx @angular/cli@^20 if ng isn’t global)
- Augments with components, SEO, animations, assets, env, tests
- Adds Angular performance budgets

After bootstrap succeeds

1) Configure and run the API
- cd .\apps\api
- Copy and edit env:
  Copy-Item .env.example .env
  notepad .env
  - FRONTEND_ORIGIN=http://localhost:4200
  - SMTP_HOST=smtp.strato.de, SMTP_PORT=465, SMTP_USER/PASS
  - MAIL_TO=your inbox
  - RECAPTCHA_SECRET=your v3 secret
- Install and start:
  npm install
  npm run dev
- Verify: http://localhost:3000/api/health (ok: true)

2) Run the frontend
- cd .\apps\frontend
- Edit src\index.html and set your RECAPTCHA_SITE_KEY
- Put real images into src\assets\
- Start:
  ng serve -o

Optional full local test with Docker
- In C:\PaderCleanv1:
  docker-compose up --build
- Frontend: http://localhost:8080
- API health: http://localhost:3000/api/health

Go live
- Follow docs\GO_LIVE_CHECKLIST.md
- Frontend: ng build --configuration production; upload dist\<app-name>\ to Strato; place configs\apache.htaccess as .htaccess
- API: npm run build; deploy dist\ to server (PM2 or systemd), set .env, front with Nginx; set FRONTEND_ORIGIN=https://paderclean.de

If anything errors, paste the last 5–10 lines — I’ll adjust quickly.
